titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Military Tradition at LSU
titleInfo.subTitle: Aubrey Williams oral history interview, 1997

name.description: Aubrey Williams was born in Jacksonville, Fla., in 1922. He attended Louisiana State University before serving in the Army during World War II. He received a B.A. degree from LSU (1947) and M.A. & Ph.D. degrees from Yale University (1948, 1952). Williams taught English primarily at Yale (1950-58) and the University of Florida (1958-60, 1961-86).

subject.topic: Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College.--Dept. of English.
Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--Students.
Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--Faculty.
Nuremberg War Crime Trials, Nuremberg, Germany, 1946-1949.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Williams discusses his experiences attending Louisiana State University including his time spent studying journalism and working for the Morning Advocate; studying in the English Department; student and fraternity life; military training; the Southern Review and The Reveille; various faculty members; and anecdotes about Cleanth Brooks, Robert Penn Warren, Katherine Anne Porter, and John J. Tigert. He describes his service in the Army during World War II, including witnessing the Nuremberg Trials. Williams discusses his attendance at Yale University including studying under Maynard Mack, teaching courses, and spending a year on fellowship in England. He also discusses his teaching at the University of Florida including the Johns Committee, the pressures of affirmative action, the poor quality of its English students, the saga of Council Bly, and English Department politics.
